text: The year is 2040. Everyone has to verify their identification via ice ganners and fingerprint machines. You can't legally order a pizza without verifying your social credit score is above 419. In order to chat with the boys, discord checks your government ID to make sure you're old enough to see anime memes. Nobody remembers the time when you could simply open up AIM and send your friend your new Hello World print implementation without five-factor authentication. I'm in the woods with Luke Smith talking to nobody because we both refuse to allow the snowball effect to occur with respect to surveillance, but I'm not alone. Enter the matrix. What's up guys, my name is Tony. And today I'm going to give you a quick and painless guide on matrix. In light of discord's recent announcement of their age inference model and identification verification coupled with the fact that discord is proprietary garbage anyway. There are much better options out there. Matrix is one of those options. Matrix is an open standard for decentralized encrypted communication. It's similar to email in that anyone can run a server and all servers talk to each other. What makes matrix special is it's got decentralized federation which allows servers to talk to each other and there's no single point of control. The messages are encrypted by default and to end. The protocol is fully open source so that means it's fully auditable. You're not locked into one specific client or even one specific server implementation. And there are persistent rooms similar to discord servers so it's not just group chats. For today we're going to show two paths to matrix. One is the normy path of least resistance which is simply setting up an account on matrix.org and joining a public room as needed. And the second path is going to be for the self-hosting enthusiast which I will show how to do and explain why it is a superior path. Both are better than discord though so let's jump right into the tutorial. All right so let's set over to matrix.org and click try matrix. And at this tiny little banner kind of bothers me so I'm going to get rid of it here. I'm just going to right click this div right here and delete that node. All right so let's go back into this. So there are tons of clients available and today we're going to go with some electron solop called element but it is clean and polished and kind of looks like discord so it is usable. It's in nix packages and for legacy distros it should be in Pacman, App, DNF and Portage etc. So let's go ahead and click on this here and we're going to use it on our browser today. So before we jump into the self hosting installation tutorial I do want to explain a small federation caveat. Now with matrix federation if you allow users on your home server your home server caches everything from any federated server that those users interact with. So if you have a user on your home server that joins some random matrix.org server then every single message is cached from that server into your home server which means you're now liable for all cached content including content you never saw or approved. This makes you potentially liable for a legal content that you never even knew about and this is why I prefer XMPP as a protocol because it doesn't have this problem but you can also simply avoid this by either doing a what I do is not allowing any registration on your server but make it public facing or be just use a matrix.org account instead of self hosting and then you're not actually caching anything because matrix.org is the server. We're going to need a domain name which you can get for three bucks a month and then you're going to need an internet connection. So we're going to set this up in our closet on a think pad and we are going to use a subdomain of the domain I already own which is tony by the way.com and then we are going to use nixowest today for deploying this server because it's declarative.
